title: 106_hr2249
content: The Act titled "Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 1999" serves the purpose of preserving the Corinth battlefield. The Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 1999 authorized the establishment of a center to interpret the Siege and Battle of Corinth, enhance public understanding of the Civil War, and coordinate with governmental entities, private organizations, and individuals. The Corinth Battlefield was identified as a priority 1 battlefield in need of nationwide action by 2000. The Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 1999 authorized the establishment of the Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park in Mississippi to protect historic sites related to the Civil War battles fought in and around Corinth. The Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 1999 established Military Park in Corinth, Mississippi and Tennessee to manage Civil War resources. It directs the Secretary of the Interior to work with various entities for protection and interpretation. Additionally, a special resource study will identify other Civil War sites in the area. The National Park System criteria for designation includes appropriateness for inclusion in the unit. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Map, Park, Secretary, and Unit. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF CORINTH UNIT OF SHILOH NATIONAL MILITARY PARK. The Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park is established in Mississippi and Tennessee, comprising approximately 20 acres including Battery Robinett and the site of an interpretive center. Additional suitable land may be included as determined by the Secretary. The Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park in Mississippi and Tennessee, including Battery Robinett and an interpretive center, has been identified by the Siege and Battle of Corinth National Historic Landmark Study. The map related to this area is available for public inspection in the office of the Director of the National Park Service. The Secretary may acquire land within the Park boundary through donation, purchase, or exchange. Land can only be donated by the States of Mississippi and Tennessee or the organization "Friends of the Siege and Battle of Corinth." Park management and administration are also addressed. The Secretary administers the Unit in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act and the Act for preservation of historic sites. Duties include commemorating and interpreting the Siege and Battle of Corinth and other Civil War actions in the area. Duties include commemorating and interpreting the Siege and Battle of Corinth and other Civil War actions in the area. The Act aims to identify and preserve surviving features from the Civil War era in Corinth, including the role of railroads, the Corinth contraband camp, and the development of field fortifications as a tactic of war through cooperative agreements with public and private entities. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to private sectors, colleges, universities, historical societies, state and local agencies, and nonprofit organizations for the conservation of historic, cultural, natural, and scenic resources in the Unit, particularly related to Civil War resources in Corinth area. The Secretary can provide technical assistance for conservation of resources in the Unit to various entities, including the State of Tennessee, governmental entities, nonprofit organizations, and private property owners. The Secretary is not authorized to own or manage resources outside the Unit. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF SPECIAL RESOURCE STUDY. The Secretary will conduct a special resource study of land in and around Corinth, Mississippi, and nearby areas in Tennessee related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth in 1862. The study will identify resources and historic themes associated with the battle. The special resource study will focus on themes related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth in 1862, including the role of the railroad, the Corinth contraband camp, and field fortifications. Potential partners to support the study include State entities. The special resource study will involve State entities, historical societies, civic groups, and nonprofit organizations to identify alternatives for land use conflicts. The report must include cost estimates for acquisition, development, interpretation, operation, and maintenance. The Secretary must submit the findings to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate within 1 year and 180 days of funds availability.
